segments.text: AWS solutions architect associates
certification prep question 22 of 65. A
financial services company operates a
real-time training application in their
on-remise data set. So they are
extending the application to AWS and
they're going to require private
connectivity with consistent low latency
under milliseconds. So network jitter is
unacceptable for trading operations. So
they need the highest performance
possible and highest consistency
possible. The compliance team also
requires an encrypted backup connection
that can take over just in case the
primary connection fails. So which two
solutions architect implement? We're
going to select two. So let's identify
the key hints. One, private
connectivity, meaning not over the
public internet. Number two, consistent
low latency. So we want predictable
consistent performance. That's number
two. Number three, real-time trading. So
any kind of network impact or jitter or
you know misordered packets
unacceptable. Number four, encrypted
backup connection. So, we need the
ability to have a primary and fail over
with an encrypted backup. So, let's look
at the options. Option one, establish an
AWS direct connect connection to AWS as
the primary link. Option [music] two,
configure an AWS sight to-sightVPN
connection as the backup. Option three,
connect the data center to AWS over the
public internet and use TLS encryption.
Option four, set up VPC peering between
the onremise network and AWS. And of
course, option five, let's use Amazon
CloudFront to accelerate traffic between
on premise and AWS. Drop your answers in
the comments below. So, the hint says
consistent low latency and private. So,
any public internet options are out. So,
option three, that's public internet.
It's got variable latency, variable
jitter. Fine for backups, but not for
real-time trading, especially as the
primary link. Option four, VPC pairing
only works between VPCs inside of AWS.
Can't connect to on-remise data centers
yet to AWS. Option five, CloudFront is a
content delivery network for basically
layer 7 content delivery. So it doesn't
really provide data center connectivity
for these kinds of private connections.
So the correct answers are options one
and options two. So direct connect
dedicated private connection with
consistent latency, no internet, you
know, variability, so no internet
weather, perfect for real-time trading.
Sight toightVPN as the secondary runs
over the internet but provides
encryption. It's a lower cost backup
that meets the encrypted requirement. Of
course, you won't get the same level of
consistency, but you can also fail over
automatically. Takeaway: Direct Connect
for consistent performance. VPN for
encrypted backups. This is the classic
hybrid network connectivity architecture
pattern. Direct Connect gives you the
speed, VPN gives you the resiliency.
Together they cover both requirements.

fullText: AWS solutions architect associates certification prep question 22 of 65. A financial services company operates a real-time training application in their on-remise data set. So they are extending the application to AWS and they're going to require private connectivity with consistent low latency under milliseconds. So network jitter is unacceptable for trading operations. So they need the highest performance possible and highest consistency possible. The compliance team also requires an encrypted backup connection that can take over just in case the primary connection fails. So which two solutions architect implement? We're going to select two. So let's identify the key hints. One, private connectivity, meaning not over the public internet. Number two, consistent low latency. So we want predictable consistent performance. That's number two. Number three, real-time trading. So any kind of network impact or jitter or you know misordered packets unacceptable. Number four, encrypted backup connection. So, we need the ability to have a primary and fail over with an encrypted backup. So, let's look at the options. Option one, establish an AWS direct connect connection to AWS as the primary link. Option [music] two, configure an AWS sight to-sightVPN connection as the backup. Option three, connect the data center to AWS over the public internet and use TLS encryption. Option four, set up VPC peering between the onremise network and AWS. And of course, option five, let's use Amazon CloudFront to accelerate traffic between on premise and AWS. Drop your answers in the comments below. So, the hint says consistent low latency and private. So, any public internet options are out. So, option three, that's public internet. It's got variable latency, variable jitter. Fine for backups, but not for real-time trading, especially as the primary link. Option four, VPC pairing only works between VPCs inside of AWS. Can't connect to on-remise data centers yet to AWS. Option five, CloudFront is a content delivery network for basically layer 7 content delivery. So it doesn't really provide data center connectivity for these kinds of private connections. So the correct answers are options one and options two. So direct connect dedicated private connection with consistent latency, no internet, you know, variability, so no internet weather, perfect for real-time trading. Sight toightVPN as the secondary runs over the internet but provides encryption. It's a lower cost backup that meets the encrypted requirement. Of course, you won't get the same level of consistency, but you can also fail over automatically. Takeaway: Direct Connect for consistent performance. VPN for encrypted backups. This is the classic hybrid network connectivity architecture pattern. Direct Connect gives you the speed, VPN gives you the resiliency. Together they cover both requirements.
